posts.cooked:
Random idea I got from another user suggesting https://file.pizza/ to send files to bypass the 100MB limit.

Is it possible to use Signal’s WebRTC functionality to do encrypted, peer to peer filesharing without having to use the Signal servers? After all, there’s an option to hide your IP by relaying calls using the Signal servers, so voice/video calls are already being made peer to peer by default.

If Signal can do high quality voice and video via WebRTC where both parties are sending/receiving data, wouldn’t it be possible for 2 users to initiate a direct p2p file transfer encrypted via the same means used to encrypt video calls?

Yes, this would require both users to keep Signal actively running, but 2 people with high speed connections could probably do a ~500MB file transfer while sending each other messages.

Imagine this: a direct transfer button, which notifies the other user that you are initiating a direct file transfer with them, and much like a phone call, you have to press yes to accept or no to “hang up”. You keep the “call” or file transfer running in the background, possibly with an Android notification telling you the progress of the transfer while you continue chatting, and you’re notified with a simple beep sound to let you know the transfer has completed.

To be clear, I’m not saying this should be the only way to send files through Signal. The default file sending function would remain, but the direct file transfer function would be a 2nd option to bypass the 100MB sending limit, with the caveat that both users have to keep the app running to ensure the transfer completes.

Anybody else interested in such a solution?

posts.cooked: Aren’t there any existing alternative apps available making this possible? For me it seems more like a kind of edge case which is unlikely to be implemented anytime soon (since it doesn’t serve the “masses”).

PiCob:

Aren’t there any existing alternative apps available

Yes, see (recently revived) discussion over here == How to transfer 300 MB file between Signal Android to Signal iPhone phones? - #15 by Patrick There are plenty of “file host services” that are household names nowadays, dropbox and google-drive and so on, and there are some cryptographically-sound and somewhat-libre-codebase services, but there are NOT any ways to perform a large file-transfer between Alice and Bob that

  • does not cost one of them (or both of them) a lot of money
  • does not require saving info to endpoint-device filesystems unencrypted
  • works for >100MB datafiles
  • needs no manually splitting/zipping/unzipping/merging
  • ideally, is integrated with signalapp
  • ideally-ideally, handles streaming (i.e. recipient can play video while still receiving it)

The thread over there was specifically discussing what happened when sending small movie-file taken from within signalapp with the phone-cam, versus a larger one. It is not supported, and my presumption (explained over in the other thread) is that the byte-cap on file-transfers was related to preventing a potention DDoS of signal-server with garbage-uploads that are rigged so as to never downloaded.

I really like the idea of using STUN/TURN to setup a direct network-socket between the ephemeral IP addr of device#1 and device#2, and then switching from vp8+opus mode to a filepicker. At all times, the transmission would be stored within the security-perimeter of signalapp, on both ends. There would be no fees to a 3rd-party hosting provider. And signal-server would never need to store the entire file being transmitted, because at any given point, if one of the devices went offline, signal-server could simply cease relaying packets. All the retry-logic would be client-side. And in the situation where relay-all-calls was turned off, which is the default setting in signal4smartphone, the file-transfer portion would not even go through signal-servers at all… endusers would just be doing a device-to-device copy via wifi, basically.

Kudos for @Halcyon to come up with this idea :-) Beautiful methinks. Not positive it can be actually implemented, there are some potential technological hangups and some serious UI/UX difficulties involved. But the fundamental idea is sound: instead of having device#A push an entire encrypted 333MB videofile to signal-server (or to S3 if that is what happens under the hood nowadays), instead device#A can negotiate a direct socket-stream to device#B and send the datafile thataway.

p.s. With a bit of care, the transmission could even be implemented as a streaming of the datafile, so that the recipient on device#B could view the movie in realtime, without waiting for the full transmission to complete. And with groupchats, device#A and/or signal-server can perform a multicast so that the sender is able to submit one single datastream, and an entire groupchat-worth of recipients can view the datastream (in realtime if they are online or “paused” if they are not). With any luck, we can eventually put together N-way videoconferencing, on this basis.

posts.cooked: It’s not a high priority feature, but I can see a lot of people, including the devs being interested in this because it would save the Signal servers from having to deal with as many files and many people would prefer a direct transfer rather than sending a file to a server they don’t own.

https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-iOS/blob/master/Signal/src/call/PeerConnectionClient.swift#L54-L56

There is a datachannel in the webrtc session already, typically used for e.g. ConnectedMessage at the beginning and then Hangup at the end of a cryptocall … but likely it can also be utilize during a cryptocall for file-transfer, or perhaps “before the cryptocall starts” i.e. prior to ConnectedMessage being sent (and in the file-transfer-only situation once the datafile is sent no ConnectedMessage might ever actually be used at any point).

According to e.g. this python-wrapper-around-webrtc-datachannel project, Data Channel transfer rates are a bit low · Issue #36 · aiortc/aiortc · GitHub , it is possible to send bytes fast enough via the webrtc datachannel to achieve realtime streaming perhaps, with a little tuning. (The videofile mentioned that was ~300MB in size above, would take just under a minute in a ‘perfect-network’ phony test on a loopback x86-class cpu… whereas the video duration during playback was over two mins… which gives a rough indication this datachannel can actually be speedy enough for large files and streaming video, with luck.)
It would be great if one of the devs could address the possibility of using this for the feature I’m talking about.

Well, there are only two devs that regularly commit to Signal-Android nowadays (either direct or via private dogfooding repo), and only two that regularly commit to signal4ios (ditto about the mechanism). So rather than ping them immediately, I suggest we work through the feature-request a bit more: it looks like we can get the speed fast enough, but what about the UI/UX portion, and what about avoiding the need to have both devices constantly online and running at all times?

Halcyon:
  1. encrypted, peer to peer filesharing
  2. without having to use the Signal servers
  3. for two users to initiate a direct p2p file transfer
  4. require both users to keep Signal actively running
  5. a direct transfer button
  6. notifies [recipient] you are initiating a direct file transfer
  7. [they] have to press yes to accept or no to “hang up”
  8. file transfer running in the background
  9. notification telling you the progress of the transfer
  10. while you continue chatting
  11. beep sound to let you know the transfer has completed
  12. default file sending function would remain

The main problem is step#4 because signal is supposed to be async by design. I think we can solve that, to a large degree. Using the webrtc datachannel means we are already going to be chunking up and packetizing the 300MB datafile. If the datachannel has a hiccup, or even a major dropout (recipient and/or sender put their device into airplane-mode or something), we can always resume the transfer later, with client-side retry-logic. That will make the file-transfer magic async, just like with a 99MB datafile.

But I would argue that we need to rethink the UI-related steps as well: step#5, step#6, step#7, step#9, step#11. Can we not just integrate the 100MB+ file transfer ability, into the existing UI/UX that is used for 99MB-and-smaller file transfer?

Alice sends Bob 'large' 9MB and 'v.large' 99MB datafiles

Right now, if Alice wants to send a 99MB file to Bob, she taps home > signal > Bob-conversation > plusIcon on smartphone or paperclipIcon on signal4desktop > galleryIcon or fileIcon > selects the 99MB datafile from the filepicker > optionally adds a textual caption > sends. Under the hood, the file is encrypted, pushed server-side (not sure if it goes direct to the S3 attachment-bucket at amazon from Alice or goes to signal-server first before getting to the storage-backend), and then stored temporarily until Bob’s device is available to receive.

Usually he is, in which case even with a 2G dataplan (on Bob’s end or on Alice’s or both), Bob will receive the 99MB datafile in under an hour or thereabouts… whereas if both are on a “typical consumer broadband internet connection” the transfer might only take a couple of minutes (usually the bottleneck is Alice’s upload-bandwidth). That is a worst-case scenario with current settings: more typically, Alice would send 9MB datafiles (meme-sized video-clip of a few seconds duration or massive spreadsheet or high-rez imagefile or whatnot), which takes under 10 second on broadband and just over five minutes on crappy 2G dataplans, roughly.

And of course, datafiles of >100MB in size cannot be sent at all, Alice gets an error-message and has to fallback on a workaround (splitting the datafile up with 7zip beforehand or using an external file-hosting service or whatnot).

So the problem with sending 333MB and 555MB datafiles, is that even on broadband connections they can take a significant amount of transfer-time: several minutes of transfer-time even if both ends have high-speed-upload, maybe half an hour if the upload-speeds are especially crippled (as they often are in cheaper consumer broadband-packages). On some kind of 2G dataplan-fallback, four hours to seven hours of constant uploading AND downloading time, even if only one device is on 2G … long enough one side will likely run out of battery-life before the file-transfer is 100% complete, in other words.

Suggested UI/UX for direct file-transfer: same as existing UI except we add progress-meters to both chat-bubbles, and do all the auto-negotiation of webrtc data-channel under the hood without user involvement

To me, the key here for a pleasing UI/UX is firmly within step#8 and step#9 == file transfer should happen in the background, but if it is going to take a long time, there needs to be a progress-meter (and the usual pause-button and cancel-button controls). So my suggestion is that we integrate the >100MB direct-data-transfer feature, into the normal UI/UX steps that Alice and Bob are already familiar with. Instead of erroring out, though, if the datafile is larger than a certain size-in-bytes, OR if the transfer is taking longer than a certain number of seconds-in-duration, we should display a progress-meter-widget on both ends of the conversation.

As the sender, Alice will see a chat-bubble appear on the righthand side of her chat-history… that is the place her progress-meter ought to appear. Bob is the recipient, and he will see an incoming chat-bubble from Alice on the lefthand side of his chat with her – this is where his progress-meter ought to appear. Either side can pause a transfer (e.g. until they are on wifi again and off their crappy 2G roaming dataplan), either side can cancel a transfer (“hang up” on the datafile). There is already code to show a simplistic progress-meter on the recipient’s side, which is a percentage-spinner with no cancel-button and no numeric indications of filesize or network-speed. There is also an upload-progress-spinner (again simplistic). However these are async and indicate sender-to-signal-server for one of the progress-meters, and signal-server-to-the-recipient for the other progress-meter. My suggestion is, when sending a webrtc-datachannel payload, to have simultaneous progress-meters on both ends (and to add cancel-buttons and some ETA details and other numerics).

Under the hood, the decision can be made on a case-by-case basis, whether to send the datafile as a normal file-attachment relayed via signal-server and the S3 attachments-bucket backend, or to instead auto-initiate a webrtc connection and use the datachannel. This can (and I would argue should) be entirely left up to the signal4smartphone app of the sender … or for that matter, the signal4desktop app of the sender, no reason signal4desktop cannot send massive datafiles via libjingle just like phones. The enduser does not need to have a special button for initiating a direct webrtc datachannel transfer, if the client-app can just figure out how to Do The Right Thing without endusers needing to care how it is done.

For files up to ~9MB in size, or for spotty high-latency network connectivity, the usual file-attachment backend is superior in perceived UX, methinks. Above that size, though, and given a decent-enough network path from Alice to Bob, negotiating the webrtc socket is probably going to be superior. And quite often, as a percentage of files sent, Alice and Bob will be in the same city… often in the same building… and not-that-rarely on the same wifi-access-point, where webrtc-datachannel can transfer ~1MB/s even on relatively crappy networking-gear, maybe ten times that data-rate if both endpoint-devices are 2x2 wifi-AC capable.

The main advantage to the suggestion is for Alice and Bob: they don’t have to learn anything new, to utilize the new feature-implementation. It works like they would expect, but now allows the transfer of an infinite amount of data (sending peer-to-peer means we can blow past telegram’s limit of 1.5GB… or Slack of 1.0GB or Skype of 2.0GB… and just permit unlimited filesizes). Whatsapp used to have a 16MB max video-size, nowadays apparently it is 100MB max, same as signalapp none-too-surprisingly. iMessage is somewhere in the dozens-to-low-hundreds-of-MB for max filesize. So it’s a competitive win, too. There will likely be some ‘bad press’ from the move: the MPAA and RIAA and anti-porn folks will not appreciate the idea of an encrypted messenger which allows unlimited peer-to-peer file transfers… but I suspect this is a case of bad press being a good thing for signalapp adoption and mindshare.

Devs do not have to add another button to the UI anywhere (except a cancel-button in the new large-datafile-progress-meter), and don’t have to alter most of the existing codebase. With a bit of care, in addition to permitting the sender to transfer massive existing datafiles without hitting the signal-server, we can let the enduser stream a datafile: as soon as Alice starts sending her 333MB video, Bob starts receiving… and can immediately hit the play-button to view the portion he has, while webrtc buffers the rest of the transfer in the background, seamlessly.

And hey, if we can make THAT work, it opens the pathway to let Alice send something other that a pre-recorded datafile: she can tell signalapp “send Bob a streaming video of my front-cam and what it is seeing right now” and Bob can watch in quasi-realtime… but from a chat-bubble within the usual chat-history, rather than during a manually-initiated videocall. Bob or Alice can pause that livestream at any time, and neither Facebook nor GoogleYoutube has an unencrypted copy of the videofeed. This tech would eventually permit screenshare, as well (cf Skype). Might be pretty cool, in other words :-)

posts.cooked: Nice post. I second everything you said.

5_c_d:

Can we not just integrate the 100MB+ file transfer ability, into the existing UI/UX that is used for 99MB-and-smaller file transfer?

Sure, but I think we need to make a very explicit distinction between a regular file send and a direct file send.

5_c_d:

The main problem is step#4 because signal is supposed to be async by design. I think we can solve that, to a large degree.

I think most people have chats longer than it would take them to send a large file over Wifi, plus such a transfer would run in the background with a notification so it wouldn’t be killed so easily.

As for the async question, I agree that in general it won’t be needed in most use-cases, but I don’t think it is hard to make async (in terms of the sender’s client-app having some timeouts and some retry-logic just like normal signal-messages already have). So to improve the chances of upmerging into the main repo, I’d rather follow their philosophy (#5)

Halcyon:

we need to make a very explicit distinction

What is the benefit to making the distinction? As opposed to, just letting Alice and Bob send large files the same way they send small ones, by attaching them? I agree that we need to have the UI make Alice and Bob aware that what they are sending might take longer than a few seconds, because of the filesize and/or the slowness of their network-pathway, but I thought that double-progress-meters with ETA/datarate and cancel/pause, would be enough. Quite possibly I’m missing the boat here, but please explain in more detail why you think the large-file-transfer should be a distinct UI (as well as a new underlying mechanism)

5_c_d:

What is the benefit to making the distinction?

Well for one, educating the user as to the actual difference between these kinds of transfers so they don’t try to initiate a direct transfer to somebody who may not be there to accept it. One requires immediate acceptance and the other does not.

My thinking is that when Alice tries to send a 9MB file to Bob and he is offline, signal-server will get a copy of all 9MB, and store it in Bob’s server-side queue for later delivery. Alice will see one checkmark for delivered-to-server, but will not see the second checkmark for delivered-to-Bob, until he is back online.

Later, when Alice tries to send a 555MB file to Bob and he is offline, the async-retry logic is purely client-side: Alice’s device will show her a progressbar in a chat-bubble, like this:

  • sending HugeFile.ZIP … trying to connect …
  • [pause button]   [cancel button]  
  • 0% complete, 0 MB/min, ETA unknown (Bob offline?)

Alice’s device will have sent a new kind of webrtc message via signal-server, FileOffer, and is waiting for Bob to receive it and run handleFileOffer. (This is the way call-setup works during a crypto-call via webrtc: Alice’s device sends CallOffer via signal-protocol, Bob’s device responds after running handleCallOffer, and once the webrtc channel is ready the sonar-pinging ends and the telephone-ringing begins to see if Bob swipes up to AcceptCall.)

Once he is back online, Alice’s device will be notified via signal-protocol (FileAnswer) that Bob’s device is ready to continue the webrtc handshake, at which point data-transfer will begin. If one or both of them goes offline in the middle, Alice’s side will auto-retry periodically, just like signal4smartphone already re-attempts failed sends in the rare situations where signal-server is experiencing downtime, or the less-rare situations where an SMS/MMS fails to go through right away. Once the file-transfer is complete, Bob would get a popup-notification “message from Alice: HugeFile.ZIP”

So the reason I want to handle async huge-file-transfers, is partly to align with the developer ideology tenet#5, but also partly because solving the async thing, means we can mostly keep the existing UI/UX… albeit with slight adjustments. And a lot of new stuff under the covers. I’m not sure this is the best way, but I like it better than requiring that Bob be there to receive the file.

(Similarly I wish there was a voicemail feature within signalapp, so that Alice could cryptocall Bob even when he was not able to talk with her right then.)

This would be cool but I mostly use Signal for messages not files. If I need to share a file that is large I usually email it or upload it to a cloud and share it via a link. A good cloud storage solution is sync.com. They take your privacy very seriously and you can get a free account with 5GB.

I am not against this idea, but Signal is a messaging app not a file sharing app and I feel file sharing apps are designed for larger file transfers.

And I perfer reep.io over file.pizza.

I understand your concern, but this isn’t making Signal a filesharing app. That’s more along the lines of Bittorrent clients. This is strictly about private person to person transfers, which Signal is already doing. This is just about making it possible to transfer larger files through an existing encrypted data channel.

Personally, I think all IM clients should be able to share large files. This is how Signal can do it.

posts.cooked:
Isn’t the main issue here that when big files get transferred and one ir both sides opted to hidr their IP address, the Signal proxy serivice will need a significant upscale?

I read that someone here stated ‘but the prixy service can already handke long calls so why would files be an issue’. But do recon that in oractice these file transfers will come on top of calls. With calls Signals proxy can force the conversation to increase compression, but a compressed file cannit be scaled when the proxy service is under heavy load. Further more calls tend to end o er time, while file transfers linger on until tgey complete. If the Signal proxy service would slow down the transfer to handke the load of many users, the tasks would just stsrt piking up faster than they get handled.

It is easier to overload the Signal proxy service with large files than it would be with calls or small files.

So wouldn’t such a feature simply take too much capacity?

This is true, good catch. If one or both of the people has enabled the relay-all-calls option (which is off by default but necessary if you want to hide your IP address and geolocation therefrom people you are cryptocalling with), then sending a 999 MiB datafile would still eat up signal-server bandwidth, despite going via the webRtc pathway.

There would still be some cost-savings, because the p2p transfer would not eat up any S3 storage-fees, but the bandwidth-fees are the primary expense. Server cost analysis - #5 by 5_c_d

There are two options here: one is to separate out the ability to relay-all-calls, and make it NOT apply to p2p file-transfers (that would get a second optional off-by-default option called “relay-all-p2p-file-transfers” or something like that). But I think the better option is to retain the setting as it is now, and let relay-all-calls apply to file-transfer as well as to cryptocalls. If the enduser starts to transfer a file which is greater than 100 MiB in filesize, and they have enabled relay-all-calls, then they see a prompt: “this large file-transfer will cost signal foundation bandwidth, is it alright to disable the relay-all-calls setting for this transfer only?” If they tap YesRevealMyIP then money is saved, if they tap NoPleaseConcealMyIP then money is expended on privacy (which is the job of signal foundation). Server-side rate limits and throttles would be able to prevent abuse methinks, but in addition to that, it makes sense to give the enduser the option to help pinch pennies, if they are willing.

In the long run, the best solution is to have per-contact settings for relay-all-calls, since often people will want “relay-some-calls” and will not care about others. This ties in with the whitelist/greylist feature-request thread. Whitelist/ blacklist
